values:
Wishing you all a great trip round the sun in 2010.

I have a few photographs made in England up at http://www.momentsofvirtue.com/blog/2010/01/19/photographs-from-england/

Hello All,

I now post at http://www.momentsofvirtue.com/blog/

I hope to find you all there.

Thanks,
-Shashi
Hi all. A new version of my website on Indian Wedding Photography is now online. Do have a look. Your feedback would be very helpful.

In loving memory of the many hours of entertainment that you provided me in the early 90s.

May your soul rest in peace, Michael Jackson.
The June 5, 09 issue of Open Magazine has an article about the evolution of wedding photography in India. I'm happy to note that a few of my photographs have been featured among those of others.

A: "I wanna make a lot of money. Maybe a million dollars." B: "Cool! What would you do with a million bucks?" A:"Well,...ummm...I'll sit around all day doing...nothing." B:"Dude, you don't need a million bucks to do nothing!"
**** Character of a Happy Life by Sir Henry Wotton How happy is he born and taught That serveth not another's will; Whose armour is his honest thought, And simple truth his utmost skill! Whose passions not his masters are; Whose soul is still prepared for death, Untied unto the world by care Of public fame or private breath; Who envies none that chance doth raise, Nor vice; who never understood How deepest wounds are giv'n by praise; Nor rules of state, but rules of good; Who hath his life from rumours freed; Whose conscience is his strong retreat; Whose state can neither flatterers feed, Nor ruin make oppressors great. Who God doth late and early pray More of His grace than gifts to lend; And entertains the harmless day With a religious book or friend. This man is freed from servile bands Of hope to rise, or fear to fall; Lord of himself, though not of lands; And having nothing, yet hath all.

Just back from a couple of trips, one to Cuddalore and the other to Tirupur. I really enjoyed my stay at Cuddalore, and I must say that I fancy bus journeys now after going via. KPN a few times. I just love the surypy tea served at the shops the buses halt at during the journeys. And, I spent 6 hours in a crowded unreserved compartment on the way back from Tirupur today. I now need some rest! I'm now reading a fascinating book called Creativity: Flow and the Psychology of Discovery and Invention by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. It's been a real eye-opener, and I don't remember the last book for which I made as many notes as I have while reading this one. My next stop: Mumbai, probably. See you all at Wildscreen tomorrow and the day after.

So, I'm just back in town from Goa covering a wedding held there. The more the number of weddings I shoot, the more I admire Jeff's work. He's the best of the very best I have studied thus far, and is an awesome role model to live up too. Thanks Jeff for having raised the bar so high. My next stop: Cuddalore.
***
For more than two years, this has been one of the best examples of the principles of marketing I have seen. They know their target audience to a fault, and use all that knowledge to pitch their stuff aggressively and in style. The photographs, the text and the layout are all designed to get fans to linger around leading to great brand acceptance levels. The product and price acceptances naturally follow.
In love with the road, and with my baby!

Here are a few more photographs taken on the trip to Horsely Hills and Gurramkonda.
A butterfly taking off after feeding Note it's extended proboscis, a straw like sucking structure, which it would curl in front if it's face in flight Female Asian Koel Red-Vented Bulbul Feeding Yellow-Throated Bulbul

Here's wishing you and all family members a great trip round the sun in 2009.

Happy new year!

Just got back to town after a couple of wedding shoots in Mumbai. Archie and I shopped till we dropped in the city. And what a city  it is - so vibrant, colorful, varied and welcoming. And, I read up a co-passenger's "The Last Lecture" by Randy Pausch on the Jodhpur Express to Mumbai and "Rich Dad Poor Dad" by Robert Kiyosaki on the way back on the Chalukya Express. While the former was instructive in the first few chapters, I was totally absorbed by Kiyosaki's book. And, after being introduced to Mr. T.S. Satyan through Anush's post, I'll go check out his exhibit in person, though I saw some of his photographs on Tasveer's online gallery. Here are few photographs taken on my trip to Horsely Hills with Dr. Ghorpade in October.

It's been a while.
  • Covered 3 weddings last month, 2 of them in Delhi. I have delivered online slideshows of the processed photographs and the albums for 2 of them. It feels great.
  • I have 2 weddings coming up this month in Mumbai, with a few more slated in 2009.
  • Will be traveling to Holenarasipur, near Hassan, this evening to roam around a quite town with ancient houses with wifey and to splash around in the Cavery. We'll proceed to B.R. hills on the 6th. The JLR package is a gift from wifey to me for my birthday. :-) It's been a long time since I have shot birds, and I'm excited with the loads of Bigma time coming ahead.
  • Of course, I've missed out on all the loads of excitement that Deponti, Anush and others regularly go after as I have been very busy with the post processing of the photographs and designing album layouts. But, such testimonials surely make it all worthwhile:
"...i think you have done a fantastic job. i love the mood. and will definitely be recommending you to people i know. also wanted to mention that we all appreciated your style of working. unlike regular photographers, you are thoroughly professional, you were not intrusive nor did anyone ever feel uncomfortable in your presence." I can live on that for a month! :-)

It feels good to make an entry again. :-) What's up? Well, let's see. Archana and I moved into a rented flat in Malleswaram. I got accepted into the Artistic Guild of the WPJA, and at the moment, it looks like I'm the only one in the country to receive such an invite. Through the India Innovation Network, I have met up with amazing beings like Rajeev Kumar. He's just 36, but the amount of lives he's packed into that span is astonishing. I enjoyed distributing books published by Ramakrishna Ashram to a school on Kanakpura Road. I have been wow'ed by Rolf Potts and his book, Vagabonding. Not many books have been read this time. I've have been going through a few of the ones I have already read.

Some of the books I have read since my last entry: The E-Myth Revisited: Why Most Small Businesses Don't Work and What to Do About It by Michael E. Gerber E-Myth Mastery: The Seven Essential Disciplines for Building a World Class Company by Michael E. Gerber Write to Sell: The Ultimate Guide to Great Copywriting by Andy Maslen When I Say No, I Feel Guilty by Manuel J. Smith Built From Scratch: How A Couple Of Regular Guys Grew The Home Depot From Nothing To $30 Billion by Bernie Marcus, Arthur Blank and Bob Andelman The Ten Commandments for Business Failure by Donald R. Keough The last one was a real let down, considering the names behind the jacket blurbs. A lot of the same old stuff that you find in every other decent book on business.
***
I have been accepted into the Wedding Photojournalist Association. I would soon be listed on their pages among those offering photojournalistic wedding photography in India.
***
I participated in the local version of the Worldwide Photowalk last Saturday. It had been quite sometime since I had been with other shutterbugs, and I also got to meet Deponti and Anush.

I took a handsome, young photographer out to dinner last week. Mahesh Shantaram quit his high-profile job in the IT industry in the U.S. to pursue his interest in photography fulltime. Conversations about his extensive travel experiences, his prior work on capturing lives in the metros around the world and his "zero-balance" lifestyle filled up the three hours that we were together. And, apart from picking up some clever ideas about his business - which he willingly shared with me -, I was introduced to the photography of Nick Brant and Martin Parr. Nick Brant's work is exactly what I have been looking for all over the web for innovation in wildlife photography. Man, does he deliver! His black and white images of the big mammals in Africa are breathtaking with their lighting, composition and drama. Surely, his work points to a new frontier in capturing the natural wonders of the world on camera. After getting tired of seeing all labeled mugshots of creatures around - some of them no doubt wonderful-, I'm inspired by Nick's vision.
***
I browsed through Sandesh Kadur's work on the Sahyadris at a bookstore. I have heard of him in general photographic circles. He must have spent quite some time among in the ghats to capture many of the photographs in the book. While the print quality and layout of the coffee-table reference work is excellent, the textual matter that is supposed to augment and explain the photographs totally lack in breath and detail. And, the book costs a bomb. Many say their work is targeted at conservationists and at people who are willing to protect what we have left of the wild but who need some help to get started. I wonder how many such stripling guardians-of-nature would buy works like these.

I was wondering if anybody could provide me with some answers to the following:

1. How could I quickly and effectively learn to make movies with sound, using photographs, in Adobe Flash?
2. What are the procedures and legal requirements to register an online business?
3. Should products like CDs and DVDs shipped abroad for revenue pass through customs?
4. Is there a cap on the amount of foreign currency that a person residing in India could earn in a given time frame?

Any pointers or contacts that would help me out would be appreciated.

Well, after about 6 months of a self-imposed hiatus, I'm back to my home on the Internet. And, apart from expressing myself in here about things I value, I sorely missed interacting with my LJ friends. And, just look at the stuff they have been up to, packing in vacations overseas, bird-watching trips, published articles, eco-tourism guidance to the uninitiated, purchases of status toys, visits to shacks that serve up delicious food and exchanging vows with their spouses all over again after decades of living with one another! It was a wonderful experience catching up with all the writing that they have put up while I was away.

The past months were used up to explore things that I haven't previously ventured into, like ingratiating myself with folks I would be seeing quite a bit, initiating myself with Kannada movies after years, learning about the components and textures of sarees, appreciating fine jewelery and their delicate construction, tuning my tone deaf ear to the phenomena of pitch variations in songs and having a close look at the lives of people who belong to the generations before mine. I have been exposed to some genuinely wealthy people and have sampled the lifestyles they lead, to those who are authentically generous at heart who don't twitch before splurging thousands on friends, to those who maintain a heartwarming camaraderie among their extended family members resulting in truly memorable bonding sessions. I have been witness to several demonstrations on the skill of nurturing a tremendous network of contacts, and how honest concern and genuine interest about the other person, put across through sweetly constructed sentences in an appropriately modulated tone, could win over people, whether they are film industry biggies, influential businessmen, retired super cops or the guy or girl next door. I have been awed by the affection showered upon the donors of monetary benefits by beneficiaries during their times of want even years after the events, by those who impress with their knowledge about maintaining huge agricultural estates while walking around in them and by the gay attitudes of those who have had to shoulder a cascade of soul-crushing troubles during their lives. I have valued my interaction with those who detail various facets of the plenty of food we have sampled, to those young kids who can strip you naked by accurately verbalizing your most private thoughts only by sitting in front of you and the hundreds of miles all of us have clocked together in my beloved car.

My partner and I have experienced a "rainbow of emotions" the past few months, from helplessness due the general stressors of wedding events and the work leading up to it, to the joy of discovering a soul with whom each could express and realize oneself. And, together with my Mother-about whom I have discovered quite a bit more through the eyes of my wife-, we hope to lead lives less ordinary.

The only time you really live fully is from thirty to sixty. The young are slaves to dreams; the old servants of regrets. Only the middle-aged have all their five senses in the keeping of their wits.  - Teddy Roosevelt
*** My new toy, among the most timely and useful of gifts I have received. Thanks a lot, Archi! :-)
A River Tern with it's catch.
We had a rocking time today on the terrace with him! :-)
A Common Krestel captured while hovering above ground, keeping its head still while scanning the land below for prey.

Archana and I attended my college buddy's wedding reception yesterday in Girinagar last evening. Shankar has been a close friend since our first meet a decade ago during our first year in engineering. His quick wit, sharp mind and refreshing presence of mind made him a delightful person to hang out with, and all our tricks played out in the electronics laboratory for three years would be etched in my memory due to his commentary on them. His folks have always received me warmly during my visits to his house were we used to brainstorm several times before exams. Manasa sure would be glad to have made such a fine conquest. God bless the couple.

Suhani Raat Dhal Chuki, Na Jaane Tum Kab Aaoge... ***
Archi! Interacting with her is like facing a firing squad. You are first stunned by the ethereal glow that rests softly on her person as she walks across sections of dappled sunlight beneath the trees around college, with the pretty patterns formed by columns of luminous sunshine gliding over her face and her luxuriant hair . The next blow is delivered when she breaks into her radiant smile in the midst of her rolling out those polished sentences, with the two senses of ours that catch such moments flushing us wonder. And, the knockout punch is delivered when she considers what you have to say with a gleam in those kindly eyes, when she offers her thoughts on the subject with all the surrounding logic that makes it valuable and when she laughs with you at your attempts at humor. And after the show's over, we can only limp back dazed into our insipid world consisting of the same old tired cares, wistfully longing to have a part of her for ourselves so as to inject some of that divine spark into our days.
Black Kites roughing it out

There are few pursuits in the world that give me as much pleasure as bodybuilding. It's one of those sports where you compete with yourself every time you do it, daring those weights you have set about to conquer, ripping apart every fibre of the muscle group you focus on by bombing it lifeless with sets whose final few repetitions are pure agony, when you simply have to push past the intense burn caused by the lactic acid that pools around the working fibres. That's when the growth is triggered, and thats when you feel like you have made it all worthwhile. And, ofcouse, grunting it out in the inspired presence of my all time favorite bodybuilder, the strong and silent one with a Ph.D. in pain, 6x Mr. Olympia Dorian Yates, would make it fun. And this, ofcourse, is my favorite post on bodybuilding. :-) The gym at Bowring Institute has reopened and I sure am gonna give those weights some serious knocking. They had better be ready!

Calling me all kinds of names to get me to post this photograph online, which he finds very heartwarming for some reason, Rohit finally had his way! :-) From the left, that's Ravi, Malini, her husband Mukund and myself. This photograph was taken by my sister at Ashu's birthday party on the 21st.
Quite a handful!
Nah, no flat tyre!
Flexing it a little! Just before the make up session on the day of his marriage
Mr. Cute! With Mommy And Daddy

Dr. Kumar Ghorpade, entomologist and ornithologist, collecting insects atop Nandi Hills. Bee flies, Horse Flies and Hover Flies were some of what he collected. Here he is disseminating some of his knowledge to us amateurs.
Birthday Boy! With Grandmom With Dad Messing with my camera bag
An immature Greater Spotted Eagle (Aquila clanga) This was shot at Nandi Hills last morning

Major Mukund has come down to Bangalore for a short visit, and I had been to his house today to catch up with him, his wife Malini, also an old friend of mine, their son Madhav and Mukund's mother. "Maddy" has grown up quite a bit since I last saw him and is, at two and a half years, not as shy of strangers as he was earlier. And not only can he understand basic Kannada, but can also speak a bit of it while demonstrating his mastery of the flying-kiss, the salute and the bye-bye hand wave. He must be quite a devil at home if one goes by the missing head and danger lights of his toy cars and his penchant for discovering how things work! Here are a few photographs I managed to make in the poor street lights I got to work with.
Maddy about to be taken on a ride on my bike by his dad
The thump of the bike was way too scary for the kid... ...but, peace rules in the end! :-)
While Mukund appeared pretty sober compared to his usual gregarious self due to him feeling the burden of several issues that needs his attention, I was very saddened to see the pallid person of his mother -with whom I get along famously-, her face drained of its trademark exuberance that used to add much effect to her words as she played her traditional role as the livewire of their household. And, the few extra pounds that she's added to her frame didn't help her appearance at all. But, I am certain that the fresh surroundings of the flat at Ulsoor into which they would move into this weekend would cause her to sizzle once again! :-) A few earlier posts about Mukund and his family can be found here, here,here and here. :-)

I would like to appreciate the help I got from , who posted my issue on the boards of INW, and , who e-mailed me the response it got from Kaushik B, following whose instructions I could get the lens to work again. It's been great guys. I hope I can return the favor someday! :-)

The aperture of my Nikon 50mm F1.8 appears to be stuck. Since I got it from Jayesh, it is not covered under any warranty scheme. But, I recall him saying that there exists a couple of people in Bangalore who would check the issue out and even fix it if possible. Could someone please recommend such a place? I really would like to have it back in action as I would be doing some low-light wedding photography next month. Any pointers would be invaluable.

I was really glad to note from 's entry that the winter migrants have begun their procession to our local water bodies. This would be the first time that I would have an entire winter to study the arrival of such species. My workhorse would be back from the workshop soon, my mind is willing to soak up all I can read about aquatic birds, and my trusty D50 would be ever ready to grunt it out on the fields. I'm delighted at the prospects, and I sure-as-hell am ready! And, together with fellow LJers like , and it would be a fun 5 months to live through! :-)
View from Nahargarh
PKF OWI IGH JB
